[DEFINITION] This term indicates individuals of mixed European and Asian parentage, usually those born from unions between a European and a Eurasian. [SENSITIVITY] This category reflected and imposed a classification system of people based on blood and racial differences. [CONTEXT] According to Gijs Kruijtzer, it was among the numerous terms used by the Dutch to categorise people of mixed descents based on "different grades of 'European-ness'".

Paraphrased from:
Source: Meersbergen, Guido van. 2022. Ethnography and Encounter: The Dutch and English in Seventeenth-Century South Asia. European Expansion and Indigenous Response, volume 35. Leiden: Brill. p. xvii.
Reference: https://www.zotero.org/groups/4678659/items/S5L3VNNR
pp. xvii

Source: Kruijtzer, Gijs. 2008. “European Migration in the Dutch Sphere.” In Dutch Colonialism, Migration and Cultural Heritage, edited by Gert Oostindie. Leiden: KITLV Press. p. 129.
Reference:  https://www.zotero.org/groups/4678659/items/KVXULMML
pp.  129

The definition’s sources have the geographical scope of South Asia and Dutch Empire and the temporal scope of 1500 - 1950.

[DEFINITION] "Inlander" generally means a person belonging to a country itself in contrast to a foreigner; in colonial contexts, it can be understood as indicating the indigenous peoples of the lands where Europeans arrive at, in contrast to the European settlers. According to Bosma & Raben, the label "inlanders" was used to denote Asians in 17th- and 18th-century Batavia. In this historical context, according to Hendrik Niemeijer, "inlanders" was applied mainly to the 'mardijkers' rather than to the local inhabitants of the Indonesian Archipelago. [SENSITIVITY] According to the publication Words Matter, this category was part of a "race-based system" used by the Dutch to differentiate between peoples in the colony. It is an outdated term that should be avoided in present day. [CONTEXT] In 17th- and 18th-century Batavia, people categorised as "inlander" often received poorer treatment from the church compared to those categorised as "Europeans" and "Mestizos". According to Raben, although the church proclaimed a willingness to welcome all Christians equally, such categories in contrast had the effect of separating Asian Christians from European Christians, thus deepening the ethnic and social divisions in Batavia.

This term can be understood as a demonym for Europe. At the same time, in colonial contexts, 'European' can also be understood as a status with wider meaning. According to Bosma and Raben, this term indicates individuals who were categorised by colonial law as member of the European legal body. As noted by Hanneke Lommerse, "Europeanized" Eurasians and sometimes also Asians could fall into this 'European' category. According to Deborah Hamer, 'European status' could be acquired through marriage or conversion to Christianity, thus obscuring the boundary between 'European' and 'non-European'.

Paraphrased from:
Source: Bosma, Ulbe, and Remco Raben. 2008. Being “Dutch” in the Indies: A History of Creolisation and Empire, 1500-1920. Translated by Wendie Shaffer. Singapore: NUS Press. p. 345.

A collective identity marker; a social category usually built upon and delineated by markers of membership that describe not only who one is but also who one is not. Ethnic identities can constitute self-identification by in-group members, but can also be categories ascribed by out-group actors. The shared characteristics, on the basis of which ethnic categories were recognised, could include a shared language, place of origin, status, custom, nation, or physical characteristics such as skin colour and descent, among others.

Paraphrased from:

Source: https://www.zotero.org/groups/4678659/items/5SD647NI; https://www.zotero.org/groups/4678659/items/S5L3VNNR; https://www.zotero.org/groups/4678659/items/92A584Z6.
Reference: Hussain, Serena. “Identity Categories and Colonial Legacies in the British Urban Space.” Social Identities 30, no. 3 (May 3, 2024): 190–208; Meersbergen, Guido van. Ethnography and Encounter: The Dutch and English in Seventeenth-Century South Asia. Leiden: Brill, 2022; Lyna, Dries, and Luc Bulten. “Classifications at Work: Social Categories and Dutch Bureaucracy in Colonial Sri Lanka.” Itinerario 45, no. 2 (August 2021): 252–78.
pp. 193; 10; 258-270
The definition’s sources have the geographical scope of United Kingdom, South Asia, Sri Lanka, and the temporal scope of 1600-2021.
